page.title: 02THE HISTORY OF BUDDLE LANE.
page.content: The even numbers on Buddle Lane were built in the 1930's before the 2nd W.W. They were built on open fields and an orchard. Some of the old trees are still growing in the gardens. The odd numbers were built in 1919 to 1920 just after the 1stW.W. It used to be called Monditter Terrace. They were some of the first experimental government houses to be built. There used to be an open water drain taking water from the fields behind John Stocker school to a viaduct in the pleasure grounds behind the Methodist Church. No.16 used to be a dairy with cobblestones outside. Mrs. Hook at 35 Buddle Lane told me all this. She has lived there for 61 years and remembers horses and carts along the road. by Ruth Granfield
